name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1591-10-13

Diplomatic.text: I[ustus] Lipsius Carolo Clusio S[alutem] D[icit]. Una cum litteris flores et semina a te accepi, mi Clusi, et quod soles, largus in Lipsium tuum es et benignus. Gratias habeo, quid aliud nunc possum? Utinam opes aut copia mea unquam ferant ut re exhibere gratum me possim! Sentires me certe ex animo et sine fuco tibi amicum. Ego adhuc Leodii sum et apud me nunc uxor; et domum hortumque satis commoda habeo, sed quia non solus (ita enim hic mos et plerique exteri in aedibus amplis canonicorum habitamus), non ausus sum bulbos meos horto communi credere, eosque in arculis ligneis deposui et exposui in fenestris cubiculorum meorum ad solem. Ad summam, sunt velut Adonidis quidam horti. Ego proxima aestate de tota mansione consilium capiam, si Deus volet, idque pro temporum fluxu. Spero etiam me tunc repetiturum Spadanos fontes, si tamen tuto licebit, nam Batavi praemiatores aliique illorum velo et nomine totum hunc tractum pervagantur. De Colvio quod mihi nuncias, inopinatum non est: adolescentem novi, a studiis magis quam a moribus mihi probatum. Linguae etiam intemperans valde est et saepe in malignam partem. Quid dicam, mi Clusi? Iuventus pleraque hodie, ut aevum istud est: superba, vana, petulans et non ad mores parentum. Iste qui has tibi, ut opinor, tradet, Adamus Leemputius est, viae meae et totius itineris fidus hucusque comes. Incredibile est quam auxilio et solatio mihi fuerit. Rogo te uti videas eum libenter, virum bonum et non ex genere, quod descripsi. Vale, mi Clusi. Leodii, III Id[us] Octob[res] M.D.XCI. Salvebis multum a Lampsonio nostro qui iam senescit et caput respersum gerit cana nive. Sylburgium et Brederodium saluto. [Address:] Clarissimo viro Carolo Clusio. Francofurtum. [Clusii manu:] 1591. I[usti] Lipsii, Leodio, 13 Octobr[is] novi ad meas 20 Sept[embris] veteris. Accepi Francoforti, 21 Octobris veteris, per Adam Leemputium. Respondi 31.

annotations.text: apud me nunc uxor: Anna van den Calstere arrived safely in Liège on 26 September 1591.

a studiis: After Lipsius had prepared the manuscript of Martinus Smetius’s Inscriptionum Antiquarum quae passim per Europam liber for the press, he added an appendix based on his own annotations of inscriptions which Smetius had not been able to see. Colvius had helped him with comparing his own material and Smetius’s. In the introduction to this Auctarium Lipsius extolled the zeal of his young helper (cf. Ad lectorem, 4). The work was published by Franciscus Raphelengius in Leiden in 1588. Upon hearing that Colvius was planning an edition of Apuleius, Lipsius offered him his annotitions to this author.

annotations.text: domum: Lipsius had found accommodation with canon Johannes Dullardus on the Place St.-Lambert.
Adonidis quidam horti: An expression taken from the Greek, cf. Plin. H. N. 19, 4, 19; Erasmus, Adagia, 1, 1, 4.

Adamus Leemputius: Adamus Leemputius from Utrecht had studied in Leiden en acco;panied Lipsius on his journey from Leiden to Liège, where he acted as his secretary until Lipsius's wife arrive. Next he left for Würzburg, where he obtained his degree of licentiate in Law on 16 March 1592. Immediately afterwards, he returned to Utrecht and became advocate at the Court of Utrecht,
